entry.title: Combined summary - Bitcoin-development Digest, Vol 45, Issue 37
entry.summary: The email thread discusses proposals for secure and private Bitcoin transactions, with one proposal involving using Bluetooth LE to transfer payment URI for proximity-based communication between parties. However, the conversation mainly revolves around security concerns related to broadcasting transactions publicly. The first message from Martin asks about using a short authentication phrase to verify ownership of a public key and establish that secret over a public channel. Eric suggests bootstrapping a private session over an untrusted network using a trusted public key or decentralized Web of Trust (WoT), but these methods have their limitations.In the second email, Hector Chu proposes requiring a miner's signature in the block header as a solution to mining centralization. Currently, mining is centralizing to a handful of pool operators, which could hold users hostage and change the rules to suit themselves. Chu suggests requiring each miner to sign the block header prior to hashing and paying out coinbase to the miner's public key counterpart of the private key used to sign the block header. Natanael responds to Chu's proposal, stating that increasing technical trust requirements won't help as people already trust things like cloud mining. He also notes that threshold signatures or group signatures could possibly be used by an actual distrusting pool's miners.Finally, an advertisement for the Go Parallel Website, sponsored by Intel and developed in partnership with Slashdot Media, is included in the last email. This website serves as a hub for all things parallel software development.
